comments.commentBody:
David Macfarlane:

It was Mr. Kristof who had trouble with the question, "Why don't you look after your health"? It was a legitimate question.

There was no need to take potshots at those who believe in personal responsibility just to make a point about empathy, unless, of course, his point was not about empathy.

Has the economy turned around stu?
Where do you work?

Lots of good stuff here but I disagree with Ms. Dowd that the President should have bragged about the economy before the mid-terms for the sake of his fellow Democrats. It would have made sense for him to do so only if those who were running for reelection had done at least some of that bragging.  Instead they chose to run for the hills rather than acknowledge that the economy was turning around. Ergo, they got exactly what they deserved.

According to a document (http://spec.lib.miamioh.edu/wp-content/uploads/2013/03/Cradle-of-Coaches... in a football coaches-themed collection in the Miami (Ohio) University library: "One of his younger brothers could not pronounce his name (Wilbur) correctly and called him "Weeb", the nickname he was known by for the rest of his life."
Wilbur.
I've been a Jets fan all my life.  Someone want to tell me what Weeb stands for?

If the Seahawks beat the Pats, that will be seen as "comeuppance."

If the Pats beat the Seachickens, that will be because "they cheated again."

What if the Pat blow out the Seachickens?. Oh, yeah ... That will be a "fluke."

The only reason the Seahawks are in the SuperBowl is that Green Bay gave the NFC Championship game away multiple times.

"Let’s hope they are right, because a recent Gallup Poll showed that while American tolerance toward gays has risen, race relations have worsened. The events in Ferguson, Mo., seem to reflect that sad truth." The poll does not "reflect" less tolerance. It reveals less satisfaction.

It is possible that we have become simultaneously MORE tolerant and LESS satisfied. For example, is a white person who is dissatisfied with calls for virtual disarmament of the cops in black neighborhoods necessarily racially "intolerant?" Is someone who agrees with the likely result that the federal investigation of the Ferguson shooting will exonerate Officer Wilson, racially "intolerant?" Is it "racially intolerant" to harbor a negative opinion of Al Sharpton' antics? Or is it merely "unsatisfying" to come to terms with all these things?

It seems to me that an objective economic analysis would find a significantly higher degree of racial tolerance in this country than existed in past decades. Much of it comes through commerce. Observe, for example, the pervasive presence of non-Caucasians on television programming and advertisements. It would not surprise me if commercial television advertisements have become more racially diverse than PBS programming.

Ferguson is evidence of significant race problems that remain in the US, but the events there support neither Professor Cowen's overall contention in the article, nor his interpretation of the Gallup Poll.

Kevin had Medicaid, for years. Medicaid is 100% free. No copays, no premiums, no deductibles. He had access to doctors, hospitals, tests, medication, etc.

Medicaid even pays for gastric bypass surgery.

Though Mr. Kristoff makes Yamhill sound like it is in outer Mongolia, in fact it is an exurb bedroom community of Portland Oregon -- about a 30 minute drive. Portland is a large city with excellent medical facilities.

Most people will try to find a way to explain why  this could never happen to them and how it was Kevin's fault. I suspect that Kevin did not have access to doctors except at the emergency room level. If this is true, he might have lived longer had doctors coached him on his health or otherwise had intervened earlier before his health problems became so critical

"Here's a simple solution: let every team inflate their footballs to whatever pressure they like. No one gains an advantage if everyone is allowed the same freedom."

Good post. In some sense, that is the current regime. There is a range, but the range may be both unnecessary and too narrow.

The Catholic church is ok with Americans and other 1st world Catholics ignoring official doctrine, because they seem to hang around anyway, mostly out of a "cultural connection" to the faith. (I figure this will decline once the disapproving grandmothers gradually disappear.)

But the real reason the church doesn't change is that high birthrates are the main driver for the continuation of the church. If the world's Catholics stop having as many children, the church will lose power. And, of course, that's what it's all about.

Mr. Obama got where he is by not being confrontational. He did what he could to keep things smooth and not get people mad at him.

Then he got elected with an opposition that was as obstructive and mean spirited as any president ever had. He tried to be bipartisan, but they used that against him. it has taken him this long to be able to change from a pussycat to a tiger, if he has. He just did not know how to take them on, thought reason and the good of the country would do it.

As we have seen they do not care about the good of the country, the general welfare, if people can buy a meal, or send their kids to school with breakfast and lunch. What they care about is the welfare of corporations run by right wing ideologues, who want to turn the country into a corporation, run by them.

He was just too nice, not a TR or FDR, or even a Truman.
To cerebral, let them get away with bringing the country to the bring of economic failure, by appointing a bipartisan commission to investigate.

Even though Bush and his crew of cave men sent thousand to die, put the country into debt, created the atmosphere for the Islamic terrorism, the GOP blames him for it, with a series of continuing prevarications.
They just got away with it again, and are working to dismantle the protections put in place to prevent it from happening again.

A Pox on them.

An illustrative portrait of the consequences of labor's losing both political power, through unlimited funding of politicians by monied interests, and negotiating power, through the large influx of unskilled workers.  I suspect, however, that Mr. Kristof would only support addressing the former of these problems.

The photography in this magazine is consistently of high quality. The stories are varied in their scope, informative, and inspirational. The print quality and page feel are spot on. I seek those things in a publication.

It actually IS a taste of the world of agriculture and farming, albeight in a highly glamorous and polished fashion. It's ironic that one of my favorite articles argues against jumping into farming; because it is extremely hard work for little pay. In short, I will miss experiencing this "clumsy hybrid of farm and chic" from the comfort of my recliner, and wish its talented editors all the best in their future endeavors.

"But what if the wealthiest and most powerful among us were willing to view themselves ... simply as more fortunate — and, therefore, called to ensure fairness for those less fortunate."

Beautiful ideas like this are great precepts for living one's own life. But this one is nearly useless -- or even dangerous -- for defining social policy because, let's face it, it's not going to happen. History is clear on this. Remember "Compassionate Conservatism"?

The Unites States has benefited from much good fortune, not least of which has been the strong (and reasonably honest) rule of law. We take that for granted but we shouldn't -- fair, practical and ethical laws, honestly enforced, make much possible.

So while I'm good with the nice "what if" ideas personally, the way forward must be to demand legislation to achieve the same ends, and to demand enforcement. While we remain a true democracy, this shouldn't be that difficult. Thereafter it could get ugly.

It's de Blasio who's managed to divide by race by so closely aligning himself with Sharpton and Noerdlinger, the mayor's wife's chief of staff who used to work for Sharpton.

Sharpton is a divisive figure. De Blasio adores him and has even stated that the more people go after him, the more he likes Sharpton. Those are not the actions of someone who's trying to avoid racial divisions.

I agree that he needed therapy. But nobody ever taught him to reach for it. You have a very superficial understanding of what it takes in a person to be able to reach out for therapy and of what being demoralized does to you. The result is that you are exactly the kind of person Kristof is writing about.

As for your comparison between Kevin Green and 2 dogs, I wonder if you realize it, but you're basically saying somebody should have put him out of his misery because he couldn't recognize that he needed therapy.

You only have empathy for what makes sense to you. True empathy is feeling for a person when you don't understand why they're behaving the way they are, when you're willing to set aside your own prejudices and judgments and ask them, not as an accusation "what's WRONG with you" but genuinely wanting to understand.

Well--as a person who has been depressed and hospitalized for it I do understand what depression and being demoralized can do. You certainly showed your deep lack of empathy (and understanding on the intellectual level) in your response to my comment. You made all kinds of assumptions that were not warranted about me, and in fact, this is the issue I have with this anecdotal essay. Did Kristoff talk to Kevin's common-law wife etc etc? Sounds like he only talked to the brother. We need a lot more info to know what took place. If you are in a rut (physically and mentally) you have to try and get out of it with all your strength. I am not saying this guy did not do that. My point is that when people stop trying that's when it gets hopeless and no amt of empathy will help them, esp. from afar.

I am wondering how he did not have enough $ to get married (as the article says) yet he had 2 kids? Ballooning to 350 pounds is bound to bring major health problems, and it did. Why could he not lose weight or start exercising or be more active/ride a bike? He was depressed, according to his brother (no self-esteem). You don't mention his family/parents--where were they? He needed therapy I guess after losing his job, kids, partner. This is devastating. His sister died at 52--sounds like the family is pretty unhealthy and the photo of Clayton shows an obese person. I have empathy for wild creatures who are starving from an impoverished habitat due to human greed. I have empathy that he tried to be entrepreneurial and grow and sell a product. I have empathy for his kids. He should have donated his body to a research hospital (free of cost) and given the $3k to his kids. He made a lot of bad choices and needed guidance. Too much empathy is not the answer. There was something broken here and he needed to find help to regain his will to live. I rescued dogs (2) and spent  a lot of $ on their care (they were very ill)--I had empathy. Now I wish I had put them down humanely and given the $ to save wild animals that face extinction on this overcrowded planet.

All religions are based on theistic beliefs, written by primitive men, usually ignorant and prejudiced, as attested in their 'holy books'. They are dogmatic as well, hence, unable to change and accommodate to modern societies' needs. And forbidding contraception is one of them. Once people become educated, they are less and less willing to suspend reason for a doctrine demanding blind faith in 'teachings' that do not make much sense. Pope Francis is, no doubt, a decent and honest man, but assigned to do the impossible, transmit infallibility to his preaching. And we have empiric evidence that most Catholics do ignore the prohibition in using 'the pill'.

@Jonathan: the Republicans won't be able to come up with 100 things the President would object to unless they cite "Obamacare" 100 times.  For them the concept of governing is just a euphemism. They'll be more or less out of ideas after Keystone is vetoed.
The harder people work the luckier they get. Having kids you can't support is dumb and selfish.

I'm so sorry about your friend. Stories like this are heartbreaking, and all too common. People who think there is equal opportunity in this country are delusional. I would love to hear people in the top 5% admit that though some of them do work hard. most of them have also been pretty lucky. Let's help our youth realize their potential and level the playing field by supporting President Obama's initiative to provide 2 years of free community college to anyone who wants it. Give people the opportunity to succeed, and all of us will benefit.
My first thought was HAME, which I'm pretty sure has something to do with horses.
Loved the twisted endings. My favorite was A QUARTER TO TOW. I had rein before MANE, too. My experience with riding with no bridle is that the horse goes where it wants. I want reins, thanks.

The reason this asbestos sham perpetuates is because there are whole industries, including asbestos abatement contractors,  lobbying for its continuance.  Whenever topic of asbestos comes up, I always ask "how come you can't  name anybody who came down with this disease from casual exposure?"

And my question for RCH is, what is the response of conservatives who think it isn't the government's responsibility to care for it's poor, disabled, undereducated, etc., then what is to be done about the issue of no birth control and no abortions. I have never understood those who complain about people having too many children and then not allowing them to control the number of children they have. And the big thing that was noted is the lack of jobs in this country that pay a living wage. That is a responsibility of the government.
As opposed to her lightning bolts about George Bush?

Barbara, I think you mean that Ms Dowd, like so many aging seniors, has become repetitive and boring.

Full disclosure:
I am an aging senior (72.5 yo) and do my very best to be able to express new ideas and keep the folks with whom I speak interested!
And I don't get big bucks to write a NYTimes column.
Ms. Dowd,  You disdain for Obama is clear and unabated.  In your view he never did or does anything worthwhile.  Every column you have written about him is the same.

Oh, but once your are middle-aged and big, you're going to stay big. It isn't fair and doesn't make much sense, but that is the reality.

Plus, the diabetes, joint pain, and congestive heart failure that usually go along with Kevin's physique would have eliminated the sustained high heart activity that defines weight loss.

Once you hit thirty, The Party Is Over.

I can't figure that out either. He had access to fresh, healthy food. He is described as an avid gardener and fisherman.

Kevin got food stamps, and you can use food stamps to buy pure junk. You can also easily sell food stamps, to get some cash to buy drugs.

The article is very honest in saying that Kevin was a lifelong pothead. Marijuana has a tendency to remove motivation and focus, and the heavy users I know are all JUST like Kevin -- they slack off, sit around all day, have no goals and they avoid work.

With drug testing at jobs, heavy marijuana use would make job hunting nearly impossible. You'd be flunking drug tests left and right.

Drug use is a choice. Kevin MADE THE CHOICE to be a drug user. So did his two sons. Gee, I wonder why? what kind of role model did they have?

Note: Kevin was on Medicaid. Medicaid pays for gastric bypass surgery, 100% -- no copays, no premium, no deductible. He had this option and did not take it.

Kevin had a large vegetable garden and also lived off fish.  He couldn't drive so he presumably had to walk places.  Not really a recipe for obesity.  Must have had a strong genetic tendency to obesity - which is also seen in his brother.  Bariatric surgery has helped a few once obese friends of mine regain their health and might have helped Kevin.  Sorry you lost your friend.  I'm the same age, give or take a few years, and I'm always shocked to see old friends of mine die in their 50s.  It should teach us all to strive to appreciate each day, whatever our health or financial situation.

My wife and I saved for our son's education. He graduated with no debt and was given a $15,000 CD as a send off. His job was to get the best grades possible which he did. He graduated Summa with a double major in Civil Engineering and Construction Engineering and Construction. He has never had to look for a job, the jobs look for him. Having children comes with a responsibility to those children and to society.

The first thing she could do is leave New Jersey a state with the highest real estate taxes in the country and on the verge of bankruptcy. I own three homes and pay slightly more than what I paid until recently for a home where my mother in law was living and cared for. And one of my homes is ocean front. $6800 plus a $3007 state subsidy on a 1600 sq, ft. home on barely paved roads in South Jersey is stupidity.

How lovely for you that you were able to provide so generously for your son's education. I see in another comment below that you own three homes. I suspect these facts are not unrelated to one another. Should our expectation now be that only those wealthy enough to own three homes should have the privilege of having children?

My Dad's Tuition, room and board in 1937 was $1,000. Mine was $2,000 in 1963. It was up to $4,000 by 1967. Today it is $55,000. But the median cost after college scholarships is only $25,000.
The Federal Government set up tax free college accounts after I was in school. It is the responsibility of parents to fill these accounts if they want children. Apparently, having an oversized house, trips to Disney World, and driving multiple high priced vehicles now comes ahead of tuition costs. If this is a government priority, the wealthy taxpayers should buy down the costs fo big houses and cars for the bottom 90%. If parents set their priorities on wasteful spending, the government should not be paying for the basics. The tax break alone is worth many thousands.

College costs are a part of bringing up a child. Heck, parents even cover their kids healthcare costs until age 26. The government should not be covering the costs of kids whose parents were irresponsible. The responsible parents shouldn't be "hit" twice.

Mark Thomason:

He's not an outsider. He's an insider. Executive in the Oval Office with very clear responsibilities. He cannot just choose not to do it or to change the rules of some imaginary game he's playing.

Jonathan is right. He's never been forced to act within the confines of the Executive's role.

I couldn't even stomach reading the whole story to the end - so call me uninformed.-  A garden-variety den of thieves is what the US has become at every level of government and corporate organization, from hick towns to our dear old Gotham City to Washington.   What's that?  You say you can't tell the difference between government and corporations?  Congratulations, you have just successfully defined Fascism.   We took that ball away from the "Axis" powers within my memory, at cost, and now we are playing with it.  Who could even imagine that it is business-as-usual for any elected official to have personal, discretion over a pool of money from which to toss $250K bon-bons to his friends and to enrich himself in the process? By the way, whose money is it?  No doubt this smug cabal believes they cannot sin as ordinary folks do.  They rely upon some offshoot of the Bush Doctrine, "If the President says it is legal then it is legal."  Something to that effect.  The two louts will be sentenced severely - likely to probation - having embarrassed themselves so mightily.   Here in Canada, we mine asbestos. But we are not vindictive. We do not fire hard-working asbestos miners or embarrass their bosses.  In our compassion we don't allow Canadians to use the deadly stuff.  We're happy to ship it away to countries without rules.  Hmmm.  Speaking of places without rules . . . the USA now fits that description.  Wanna buy some Asbestos?
